channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Myanmar Protests, Women Are on the Front Lines
item.description: Despite the danger, women have been at the forefront of the movement, rebuking the generals who ousted a female civilian leader.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Esther Ze Naw and Ma Ei Thinzar Maung leading a rally in Yangon on Feb. 6.

item.title: Pope’s Planned Visit to Iraq, Amid Pandemic, Raises Questions of Timing
item.description: Pope Francis has said he is determined to visit the war-torn country. But some worry that the visit will become a superspreader event in a land where the virus still rages.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A banner depicting Pope Francis in Qaraqosh, a town of Syriac Catholics, in Iraq last week.

item.title: Why Is Pope Francis Visiting Iraq?
item.description: The trip is taking place despite concerns about the pandemic and security. Here’s a brief look at why Francis is visiting Iraq, what the trip will entail and what he hopes to achieve.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Pope Francis, right, will begin a three-day trip to Iraq on Friday.

item.title: India's Covaxin Covid-19 Vaccine, Already in Use, Shows Promise in Trials
item.description: The Indian maker of Covaxin says interim results from clinical trials suggest it is safe and effective, potentially removing one hurdle to New Delhi’s ambitious inoculation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India received the Covaxin vaccine in New Delhi on Monday.

item.title: Transgender Woman Expelled From South Korean Army Is Found Dead
item.description: Byeon Hee-su, who was declared unfit to serve last year after her gender-reassignment surgery, had sued to be reinstated.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: At a news conference last year, Byeon Hee-su said she wanted “to show that I can be an excellent soldier who helps defend this country regardless of my sexual identity.”

item.title: Demanding Loyalty, China Moves to Overhaul Hong Kong Elections
item.description: China’s national legislature disclosed plans for a law that would make it extremely difficult for Beijing’s critics to hold elective office in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-democracy supporters outside a courthouse in Hong Kong on Thursday. China’s election overhaul overlaps with the trial of 47 people who were charged after they organized an election primary in July.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates: U.S. Vaccination Pace Increases to 2 Million Doses a Day
item.description: Texas and Mississippi’s steps to ease restrictions raised worries, and drew criticism from the president, that they were taken too soon, while Alabama extended its mask mandate. Italy halted a vaccine export shipment from being flown to Australia. European regulators began a formal review of the Russian vaccine, Sputnik V.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.N. Says 38 Are Killed in Myanmar in ‘Bloodiest Day’ Since Coup Began
item.description: As the military’s crackdown against demonstrators grows more deadly, the U.N.’s special representative for the country said the junta had rejected her requests to visit.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Family and relatives mourned a man who had been shot and killed by the security forces during a crackdown on Wednesday against protesters on the outskirts of Yangon, Myanmar.

item.title: Smugglers Throw Migrants Overboard; at Least 20 Are Feared Drowned
item.description: Several times in recent years, migrants trying to cross between Djibouti and Yemen have been thrown into the sea.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Migrants boarding a smuggler’s boat bound for Yemen last year in Djibouti.

item.title: Germany Places Far-Right AfD Party Under Surveillance for Extremism
item.description: It is the first time in Germany’s postwar history that a party represented in the federal Parliament has elicited this level of scrutiny as a potential threat to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Delegates arriving at a convention for the right-wing party Alternative for Germany in Kalkar, Germany, in November.

item.title: As Palestinians Clamor for Vaccine, Their Leaders Divert Doses to Favored Few
item.description: Amid a debate about Israel’s duty to supply vaccines to Palestinians living under occupation, Palestinian leaders are facing criticism for siphoning off some of the few vaccines already delivered to the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up to receive coronavirus vaccinations from an Israeli medical team at the Qalandia checkpoint between the West Bank city of Ramallah and Jerusalem.

item.title: Brazil’s Covid Crisis Is a Warning to the Whole World, Scientists Say
item.description: Brazil is seeing a record number of deaths, and the spread of a more contagious coronavirus variant that may cause reinfection.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni, Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazil is facing a spike in Covid-19 deaths and an overwhelmed health care system. A more contagious variant of the virus may be part of the problem.

item.title: Xi Maps Out China’s Post-Covid Ascent
item.description: But as Beijing rolls out a long-term plan, its top leader has also warned that “the United States is the biggest threat.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A banner depicting China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing on Wednesday, before the annual gathering of the National People’s Congress.

item.title: Protests Follow Hit Man’s Hunger Strike in Greece
item.description: Dimitris Koufodinas began a hunger strike in January after being denied a prison transfer. Demonstrations in support of him have exposed divides over how to deal with convicted terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Yannis Kotsiaris/InTime News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dimitris Koufodinas leaving Korydallos Prison in Athens in 2017.

item.title: Afghan War Casualty Report: March 2021
item.description: At least 21 pro-government forces and 22 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed
item.media:description: Transporting the body of a female doctor who was killed by a magnetic bomb attached to a rickshaw in Jalalabad on March 4.

item.title: In Iceland, 18,000 Earthquakes Over Days Signal Possible Eruption on the Horizon
item.description: The earthquake swarm is the culmination of more than a year of intense seismic activity. It could also herald decades of intermittent volcanic eruptions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The Bridge Between Continents, a footbridge linking the Eurasian and North American tectonic plates, near Grindavik, Iceland. The residents of Gridavik have been on alert for potential volcanic activity.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Myanmar’s women on the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Proposed E.U. Law Aims to Rectify Gender Pay Gap
item.description: Under a proposed law, companies in Europe could be sanctioned if they fail to pay men and women the same salaries.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: A demonstration in Berlin during the International Women’s March in 2019, calling for equal rights including closing the pay gap between women and men.

item.title: In New York, as shoppers went online, Amazon went on a warehouse-buying spree.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag and Winnie Hu
item.media:description: An employee at Amazon’s distribution center in Staten Island in November.

item.title: BBC Apologizes for Interview With Cory Booker Impostor
item.description: The network issued a correction and said it was looking into the matter, calling the interview a “deliberate hoax.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Mike Kemp/In Pictures via Getty Images Images
item.media:description: BBC headquarters in London.

item.title: The Latest Case of Vaccine Alarmism
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: 86-year-old Barbara Schmalenberger hugs her daughter after receiving the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus disease vaccine in Columbus, Ohio on Tuesday.

item.title: A college president wanted a firsthand look at dorm lockdown. Very firsthand.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Col. Mark C. Anarumo, president of Norwich University in Vermont, moved into the dorms to learn about life there and to support the students.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Germany’s AfD under surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An Alternative for Germany party convention in November.

item.title: Biden Secretly Limits Counterterrorism Drone Strikes Away From War Zones
item.description: Requiring higher-level approval is a stopgap measure as officials review whether to tighten Trump-era targeting rules and civilian safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: New temporary restrictions quietly issued by the Biden administration require the military and the C.I.A. to obtain White House permission before carrying out drone strikes in regions with few American troops on the ground.

item.title: Inspector General’s Report Cites Elaine Chao for Using Office to Help Family
item.description: The Justice Department under the Trump administration declined to open a criminal investigation into the actions by Ms. Chao when she was transportation secretary.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elaine Chao testifying before a House subcommittee last year.

item.title: In Sweden, Man Armed With Ax Injures 8
item.description: The police are investigating the attack for potential “terrorist motives.”
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene where a man attacked several people with an ax on Wednesday in Vetlanda, Sweden.

item.title: Cuomo is loosening capacity limits on New York gatherings.
item.description: Starting March 22, New York will raise the maximum capacity on outdoor gatherings at private residences to 25 people from 10, though indoor gatherings will remain capped at 10 people. The limits on social gatherings in public spaces will be raised to 100 people indoors and 200 outdoors from 50 for both. Masks and social distancing will remain required.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Office of the NY Governor, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo at a news conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Plan to Ditch the Mask After Vaccination? Not So Fast.
item.description: It’s not clear how easily vaccinated people may spread the virus, but the answer to that question is coming soon. Until then, scientists urge caution.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health care worker prepared a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at a vaccination site in San Francisco on Monday.

item.title: Viktor Orban Pulls Hungary's Ruling Party From Conservative E.U. Alliance
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary withdrew his party from the center-right grouping in the European Parliament, heading off a move to expel them over democratic backsliding at home.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary arrives at an E.U. summit in Brussels in October.

item.title: N.Y.C. doubled ‘cleanups’ of homeless encampments last year, despite C.D.C. guidance to let them be.
item.description: Clearing places where homeless people live “increases the potential for infectious disease spread,” the C.D.C. has said.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City performed 1,077 cleanups of areas where unsheltered homeless people sleep from March 1 to Dec. 12.

item.title: Los Angeles County finds fewer cases among health care workers as more get vaccinated.
item.description: New cases have fallen sharply among workers in the county’s nursing homes and long-term care facilities, which have been hot spots during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: New virus cases among health care workers in the Los Angeles County fell to 69 for the week of Feb. 14, from more than 1,800 cases during the week of Nov. 29, the county said.

item.title: With Her Job on the Line, Nicola Sturgeon of Scotland Hits Back at Critics
item.description: In testimony in Edinburgh, the first minister said she broke no rules and rejected claims of a conspiracy against her predecessor as “absurd.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Scotland’s first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, appearing before Parliament on Wednesday in Edinburgh.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Xi’s plan for China’s post-Covid rise.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Beijing on Wednesday before the annual gathering of the National People’s Congress.

item.title: At three mass vaccination sites, New York will start administering doses overnight.
item.description: Three mass vaccination sites across New York State will begin administering doses overnight, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said this week, as officials seek to use an influx of new vaccines manufactured by Johnson & Johnson to significantly expand the vaccination effort.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
item.category: Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:description: People waiting in a line this week stretching around the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Midtown Manhattan’s west side, to receive a coronavirus vaccine at the site which has been converted into a mass vaccination center in New York City.

item.title: U.S. Prosecutors Call Him a Murderer. To Ukraine He’s an Asylum Seeker.
item.description: A complex legal battle in Kyiv is shedding light on the Americans who seek battle experience with far-right paramilitary units in Ukraine — and on the F.B.I.’s efforts to monitor them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Alek Minassian Found Guilty in Toronto Van Attack
item.description: The defendant was convicted of murder and attempted murder for killing 10 people and injuring 16 when he mounted the curb of a busy sidewalk in a van in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: A vigil in Toronto in 2018 for victims of the attack.

item.title: I.C.C. Will Investigate Accusations of War Crimes in Israeli-Occupied Territories
item.description: Israel’s actions in the Gaza war in 2014 will be one focus of the inquiry. The decision to investigate infuriated Israel and was welcomed by the Palestinian leadership.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians next to their houses destroyed by Israeli shelling in Beit Hanoun in the Gaza Strip in 2014.

item.title: The pandemic disrupts Australia’s agriculture industry, exposing its shaky labor foundation.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’ve never faced a worker shortage like this in my 40 years,” said Peter Hall at his orchard in Shepparton, Australia. “I suspect for each lot of crop, we’ll just not get there in time.”

item.title: Exxon Mobil’s Chief Says It Is ‘Supportive’ of Zero-Emission Goals
item.description: Darren Woods, in an interview before an annual presentation to investors, also suggested there was common ground with Biden administration policies.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: Darren W. Woods, Exxon Mobil’s chief executive since 2017, said it was difficult to put a timeline on achieving net-zero emissions.

item.title: Christian Porter, Australia's Attorney General, Denies Rape Claim
item.description: The cabinet minister offered his defense just two weeks after a separate case in which a government staff member said she was sexually assaulted in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: “The things that are claimed to have happened did not happen,” Australia’s attorney general, Christian Porter, said Wednesday in Perth.

item.title: Romania’s underfunded health system creaks under the pressure of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Kit Gillet
item.media:description: Medical staff checking an empty ward reserved for Covid patients at a hospital in Bucharest, Romania, last week.

item.title: Yusaku Maezawa Seeks Companions for Moon Trip
item.description: Yusaku Maezawa, who previously sought a new girlfriend for the trip, issued a call for eight people to join him on a SpaceX journey around the moon.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Yusaku Maezawa in 2018 after SpaceX announced that he would be the first private passenger on a trip around the moon.

item.title: Rockets Hit Iraqi Base Where U.S. Troops Are Stationed
item.description: At least 10 rockets were fired on the Ayn Al Asad air base one week after U.S. airstrikes on Iran-backed militia positions along the Syrian-Iraqi border.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Ayn Al Asad air base in Anbar Province, Iraq, in 2019. It is one of the last remaining bases in Iraq where U.S. troops are stationed.

item.title: A Wave of Reopenings
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crowd in Columbia after the lifting of the governor’s “Last Call” order for bars and restaurants in South Carolina.

item.title: When Johnson & Johnson fell behind on its vaccines, the Biden administration stepped in to broker a deal.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Thomas and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden gave updates on the pandemic at the White House on Tuesday. He said his government had provided support to Johnson & Johnson to enable the company and its partners to make vaccines around the clock.

item.title: Corporations wrestle with the question of when to return to offices.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell, Gillian Friedman and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacori Owens-Shuler, an industrial designer, back at work in the Vivint Innovation Center in Lehi, Utah, last month.

item.title: Videos Show Extent of Myanmar Military’s Bloody Crackdown
item.description: A trove of visual evidence reveals how soldiers and the police used rifles and other lethal weapons against anti-coup protests across the country.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill, John Ismay, Christiaan Triebert and Haley Willis
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Sai Aung Main/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The police faced off with protesters during a violent crackdown in Yangon, Myanmar, on Sunday.

item.title: Without Backpackers to Pick Them, Crops Rot by the Ton in Australia
item.description: The pandemic has exposed the shaky labor foundation of the country’s agriculture industry, spurring calls for an immigration overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Hall on his orchard in Shepparton, Australia.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The ethical quandary of vaccine passports.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A senior resident wears a mask and shows her "Green Pass", a pass for those vaccinated against the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or those with presumed immunity, as she enters a live perfor

item.title: Dolly Parton, who helped fund the Moderna vaccine, gets a ‘dose of her own medicine.’
item.description: The country music star broke into song before she was inoculated, and urged her fans to “get out there and get your shot.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Dolly Parton received a vaccination in Nashville on Tuesday. The leader of the research effort, Dr. Mark Denison, said that the singer’s donation had funded its critical early stages.

item.title: U.S. Urges Ethiopia to End Hostilities in Tigray
item.description: For the second time in a week, the secretary of state pointed to reports of atrocities in the Ethiopian region.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: A damaged tank north of Tigray’s capital last month.

item.title: Biden Administration Announces Sanctions on Russia in Navalny Case
item.description: The action came as the administration declassified an intelligence finding that the F.S.B., one of Russia’s leading intelligence agencies, was responsible for the poisoning of Aleksei A. Navalny.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, was sentenced to more than two years in prison.

item.title: Possible Showdown Over Myanmar Ambassador Looms at U.N.
item.description: The military junta in Myanmar wants to replace its United Nations envoy, but he isn’t leaving. “We’re in a very unique situation,” the U.N. spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: An image released by the United Nations showing U Kyaw Moe Tun, Myanmar’s ambassador to the U.N., pleading for international action in overturning the military coup in the country last month.

item.title: Abbott Ends Texas Mask Mandate, Says Businesses Can Fully Reopen
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan, Dave Montgomery and Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tracy Davie, left, and Renee Thevenot, both wearing masks, shopping in Austin, Texas, in January.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Will vaccine passports deepen inequality?
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: At a theater performance in Jerusalem last month. Israel reopened cultural hubs for people with vaccination certificates.

item.title: How Sexual Assault Allegations Have Divided Mexico's Governing Party
item.description: Mexico’s president has stood by a candidate accused of sexual assault. The case is testing the president’s promises of justice and equality for all.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basilia Castañeda has spoken publicly about her allegations of rape against Félix Salgado Macedonio, a candidate for governor in Mexico who has the president’s backing.

item.title: In Afghanistan, Three Women Working in Media Are Gunned Down
item.description: The women, the latest victims in a wave of targeted attacks, were killed on their way home from their jobs at Enikass Radio and TV in Jalalabad.
item.dc:creator: Zabihullah Ghazi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Hospital workers and relatives moving the body of one of the three media workers killed in two separate attacks in Jalalabad on Tuesday.

item.title: Vanishing in the Desert, Traditional Bedouin Culture Lives Online
item.description: After 50 years of fieldwork in the Negev and Sinai deserts, an Israeli researcher donated his rare archive to the National Library of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clinton Bailey at his house in Jerusalem. He recently donated his archive of 350 hours of audio tape, photos and slides on Bedouin life to the National Library of Israel.

item.title: Vaccine Passports, Covid’s Next Political Flash Point
item.description: A world divided between the vaccinated and unvaccinated promises relief for economies and families, but the ethical and practical risks are high.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: At a theater performance in Jerusalem last month. Israel reopened cultural hubs for people with vaccination certificates.
